stem: The nurse is evaluating a client with a suspected Central Nervous System (CNS) infection. Match each assessment sign with its description and significance.

columns.text: Severe neck stiffness; inability to flex the chin to the chest.
Pain or resistance when extending the leg while the hip is flexed 90 degrees.
Involuntary flexion of the hips/knees when the neck is flexed.
Severe hyperextension of the head, neck, and spine (arching).

rationale.correct: Meningeal irritation causes protective muscle guarding. (r1) Nuchal rigidity is the classic 'stiff neck'. (r2) Kernig targets the 'K'nee extension. (r3) Brudzinski links the 'B'rain/neck to the legs. (r4) Opisthotonos is an extreme arching sign of severe neurological irritation or tetanus.
rationale.incorrect: Patients with bacterial meningitis require DROPLET precautions, whereas viral meningitis requires STANDARD precautions.
clinicalPearls: The priority for a patient with suspected bacterial meningitis is to initiate Droplet Precautions first, even before the diagnostic lumbar puncture.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'B-N-H' for Brudzinski: Flex the 'B'ack of the 'N'eck and the 'H'ips follow. Remember 'K-K' for Kernig: Pain when extending the 'K'nee.

mnemonic.title: K-B-N
mnemonic.expansion: Kernig = Knee. Brudzinski = Bend (Hips). Nuchal = Neck.

reviewUnits.heading: CNS Infections
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for fever, headache, and photophobia. Analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) via lumbar puncture confirms the diagnosis (Low glucose and high protein in bacterial meningitis).
